p.seg: As for study, it is practice (of what one has learnt) that is the most important.
explaining this comes second;
teaching it to others comes third.
If all these are absent in someone, then he counts as an ordinary fellow.
Someone asked:
"For a person to covet long life
and to study with this in mind,
can/should that definitely be called "fondness of study"?
Reply:
"This is not quite to be fond of it (i.e. study) yet.
To study is not to crave anything.
(One may ask:) Did not the Way of Heaven reside in Confucius?
(Reply:) Confucius was the one who braced himself for its explanation.
(One may continue:) Does the Way of Heaven not reside (now) with these Confucians of our time?
(Reply:) If one is to brace oneself for their explanation
then the best things to do is to the bronze bells with wooden clappers of the Confucians (to transmit the Way of Heaven).
1/4 Someone asked:
"Study is no use.
How does it affect the substance (of those studies essentially concerned with 文)?"
[My reply is:] You HAVE NOT QUITE THOUGHT THIS THROUGH PROPERLY.
Now, those who have knives will grind them!
and those who have jade, will polish it!
Unground and unpolished,
what use are these things (i.e. knives or jade)?
In the grinding and the polishing of these things,
SURELY THERE IS SUBSTANCE (just as there is in study.) (compare 樂在其中)
As for the young corn worms
when about to die they come upon wasps,
who implore it, saying,
"Become like us; just become like us!"
In the long run these young corn worms get to to become like them!" (As the obscure Ode Mao no. 193 reports.)
THE PURPOSE OF STUDY IS TO sort oneself out;
THE PURPOSE OF THINKING IS to give oneself subtlety.
THE PURPOSE OF FRIENDSHIP IS to polish oneself.
THE PURPOSE OF FAME IS to givre oneself pondus.
THE PURPOSE OF indefatigable enthusiasm is to go through with things.
This MAY SURELY BE CALLED "LOVE OF LEARNING".
"Confucius was the sort of person who practised the way of the Duke of Zhou;
and Yán Yuān was the sort of person who practised the way of Confucius.
If Hóu Yì and Péng Měng had snapped their bows in two,
or Wáng Liáng thrown away his whip,
or Gōngshū Bān had discarded his axe,
so so as to practise the way of these (Confucius and Yán Yuān)
who would say that they were wrong?"1
Someone says,
"These men (like Confucius and the Yán Yuān) are famous but so are others. (the others like Wáng Liáng and Lǔ Bān)
they were (each) in only one field, that is all."
Reply:
"Among the streams, there are the great rivers,
and among the mountains, there are the mighty peaks.
The elevated and the great, rivers, mountains as well as men,
these cannot be surpassed by the common run of men.
Someone asked,
"In today's world, people are always talking about casting metal.
But can gold be cast?"
Reply:
"From what I have learnt,
those who see a noble man ask about 'casting' men,
not about casting metal."
The interlocutor continued:
"Can men really be cast like metal?"
Reply:
"Confucius did 'cast' Yán Yuān."
Respectfully, the interlocutor said:
"Splendid!
I asked about casting metal and I get an answer about casting men."
As for study
it is a means by which one works on/cultivates on one's inborn nature.
Sight, hearing, speech, bearing, and reflection –
these are things that inborn nature contains.
If one studies then one becomes straight
if one fails to study one becomes depraved."
"Ah, the teacher; the teacher!
he is the destiny of the sapling (i.e. 童子child).
Striving to study is not as good as striving to find a (good) teacher.
As for the teacher,
he is the model and standard for others.
For models not to be model-like,
and for standards not to meet standards,
counts as not so rare.
On a single market in a little street
there are countless different opinions;
On a single document one scroll long
there are countless different explanations.
For one single market in a little street
one must set up a weighing mechanism for it.
For a single document one scroll long
one must establish a master for it.
"Ah, Emulation! Emulation!
By emulating what is wrong one can even overcome what is right.
how much more can one, by emulating what is the right overcome what is wrong.1
Ah!
The person who engages in study sorts what is right for him, that is all!"
Someone asks:
"But how is one to understand what is right so that one may emulate>try to live up to it?"
Reply:
"Looking at the sun and moon, one understands the puny size of all the stars,
Looking up to the sages, one understands the pettiness of all the (current) theories.
Study being the "undertaking of a true king" (see Chunqiufanlu 4),
this has been going on for a very long time.
(Already the early kings) Yáo, Shùn, Yu,3 Tāng, Kings Wén and Wǔ were fully engaged in this.
But then Confucius was really worried (about this matter, i.e. the absence of such royal study),
and that (too) has been going on for a very long time!"
Someone asked about advancement.
Reply: "It's (like that of) water."
The interlocutor continued, "Is it because it never stops, day or night?"
Reply: "That is true enough!
But only after filling something up does it make upward progress. Such is the nature of water."5
The interlocutor asked about the greater upward progress.6
Reply: "It goes on to only what it is right to go on to,
it dwells on only what it is right to dwell on.
The upward progress is indeed like that of water!"
"May I ask about upward progress in trees?"
Reply: "Remaining still below but progressing upward above --
this is the nature of a tree.
Trees behave (fundamentally) like water, that is all."
I have never seen anyone as much given to carving into shape, with an axe, his moral power as to carving into shape, with an axe, the lintel struts (in their official homes).
The birds and beasts act out impulsively their instincts.
Are ordinary people any different?
A worthy will differ from ordinary people,
and a sage will differ from the worthy.
The creation of the rites and justice surely had its purpose, didn't it?
If as a human being one does not study,
even if one be free of worries,
one is virtually indistinguishable from an animal.6
Study is a means by which one seeks to become a superior person.
There have been those who did not succeed, haven't there?
But there has never been anyone who without seeking to become a superior person succeeded in becoming one.
A horse that looks up to a famous Jì horse
will surely be a natural team-mate for Jì.
A person who emulates Yán Huí
will be natural follower of Yán Huí.
Someone asked, "Is it so very easy then to be a natural follower of Yán Huí?"
Yáng Xióng replied: "If one emulates him, that is it.
and he continued: "Long ago Yán Huí emulated Confucius.
Zhèng Kǎofǔ emulated Yīn Jīfú,3
Prince Xīsī emulated Zhèng Kǎofǔ.
If one has no desire to emulate, that settles it!
Someone asked, "If a piece of writing accords with the classics but is unappreciated in this world, would it be right to study it?"
Reply: "It would be right to do so."
The interlocutor remarked with a hollow peal of laughter: "Well, one would have to wait for the topics to be set in the exams for office!"
Reply: "When the great man studies, his aim is the Way.
When the petty man studies, his aim is personal advantage.
Are you in it for the Way or for personal advantage?"
The interlocutor continued: "But to cultivate the land but not to harvest, to hunt but not to feast on the catch – is that (really) ploughing and hunting?"
Reply: "He who cultivates the Way will attain to the Way. He who hunts for moral excellence will attain to moral excellence. This is to attain to the festive result.
One will never see Orion and Antares together in the sky.
Therefore the noble man places a high value on the improvement of his character.
Are not those who improve their character adherents of (the Way of) the sages?
All the rivers study so as to become the sea, and they do reach the sea.
Hills and mounds (may) study so as to become mountains, but they never get to become mountains:
That is why one hates those who 'draw a line' (and refuse to go beyond a certain point)."
Those who flock together are worse than crows,
for surely all they do, too, is steal those stores of grain.1
Companions not in spirit, are but companions for superficial show,
and friends not in spirit are but friends for superficial show.
Someone addressed Yáng Xióng as follows,
"The assets that you have under your control cannot compare with Dan Gui's wealth."
Reply: "I have heard that our masters (xiansheng), in discussing things with each other,
did so in terms of human-heartedness and rectitude,
and in markets or around wells, discussing things with each other,
they do so in terms of possessions and profit.
Who cares about wealth! Who cares about wealth!"
That (above-mentioned but uspecified) man continued: (von Zach, correctly: Jener sagte...
"But then, as for our masters (xiansheng), while they are alive you have nothing to feed them with,
and when they die, you have nothing to pay for their funeral with.
What about that?"
Reply: "To use what I had to feed them with
is the best sort of feeding them;
To use what I had to finance their funeral with
is the best sort of funeral."
He (the same man as in in the previous section) said:
"As for Yǐdùn's (kind of) wealth, using that to fulfill one's filial duty,
that is surely best!
Yán Huí (on the other hand) surely went hungry (himself)!"
Reply:
"Yǐdùn deployed the crude (material) part,
while Yán Huí applied the refined (moral/spiritual) part.
Yǐdùn deployed shiftiness,
while Yán Huí deployed his moral devotion.3
Yán Huí inferior?
Yán Huí inferior?? (On the contrary!)"
The man said:
"Were I to tie crimson sashes and carry gold in my breast-pocket –
the pleasure would definitely be immeasurably great!"
Reply: "The pleasures of tying crimson sashes and carrying gold in one's breast-pocket
are inferior to the pleasures known by Yán Huí.
Yán Huí's pleasures were internal
the joys of tying crimson sashes and carrying gold in one's breast pocket are external.
The interlocutor went on:
"May I ask what is so inward about 'repeatedly going empty' (as Yán Huí is said to have done)?"
Reply: "Yán Huí did not play a Confucius,
but even if he had got to possess All under Heaven that would not be enough to give him real pleasure.
(The interlocutor said:) "But he surely had his bitter troubles!"
Reply: "Yán Huí was bitterly troubled by the perfection of the distinction of Confucius."
The interlocutor, startled, continued:
"That particular form of bitter sorrows – was that perhaps just that which gave Yán gained that pleasure,?"
Yáng Xióng said: The one who had the moral teaching and established the Way, never ceasing in his efforts was Confucius.
The one who learnt to put cultivation into practice, also without ceasing was Yán Huí."
Someone objected:
"To establish a Way and "do a Confucius"
is unimaginable,
and to transmit and "do a Yán Huí"
is beyond one's strength."
Reply:
"It's that you have still not imagined it.
Who is stopping you?"
Someone asked: When young, you, sir, were fond of fù poetry.
Reply: "Indeed.
As a young boy I carved insect style seal characters.
After a short while (Yáng Xióng) continued:
Grown men don't do that kind of thing.
The interlocutor continued: Fù poetry may offer indirect criticism.
Reply: Indirect criticism! After the indirect criticism (the misbehaviour criticised) must stop.
When it does not stop I am afraid fù poetry will inevitably encouriage (such misbehaviour).
The interlocutor continued: "The fù have the transparent symmetry of delicate gauze..
Reply: “(Yes, but) they are the bane of women's (needle-)work. (This kind of delicate gauze is very impractical to work with.)
"On Swordsmen says:
'The sword can serve to take good care of one's person'"
Reply: "So feints and parries cause people to pay more attention to proper ritual?!"
Someone asked: "Is there anything to be gained from the fù of Jǐng Chà, Táng Lè, Sòng Yù, and Méi Chéng?"1
Reply: "What they could not do without was indulgence."
"If they were indulgent, what could they do?"
Reply: "The performance of specialists in shī poetry (as in the Odes) is symmetrical and regular,
while the performance of the specialists in cí poetry (like those) is symmetrical and indulgent.
If in Confucius's entourage they had employed the fù form,
then Jiǎ Yì would have made it
and Sīmǎ Xiāngrú would have gone all the way ("entered the inner chambers"
But if they Confucians did not use the fù form, where were these (cí-poetry poets like Jiǎ Yì and Sīmǎ Xiāngrú) to go?"
Someone asks about the greenfly (signifying slandering in Odes 219) and the "pink and purple" (of Analects 17.18).
Reply: "Sharpen your sight!"
The interlocutor asked: "And what about things that sound like music from Zhèng and Wèi?
Reply: "Train your hearing so that it is more acute!"
The same interlocutor asked "But (the sharp-eyed) Lǐ Zhū and (the sharp-eared) Music Master Kuàng are not of our world,
so what to do?"
Reply: "It still is surely a matter of being refined about things– there is no more to it."
Someone asked: "The same Five Notes played on the same Twelve Pipes
sometimes produce the refined elegant music and sometimes the pop music of Zhèng (and Wei)?"
How is that?"
Reply: "When the notes are exact and correct then you have the classical mode;
but when there is excessive yelling, then you have Zhèng pop."
(The interlocutor continued:) "May I ask what is at the bottom of this?"
Reply: "The Brown Bell is used to generate the tones
When they are exact and correct they make things harmonious
and they get so precise that (the pop music of) Zhèng and Wèi is unable to come into it."
Someone said: "Women have their allure.
Do books also have their allure?"
Reply: "They do.
With women, one hates it when make-up messes up their attractiveness.
Someone asked:
"Was Qū Yuán wise?
Reply: "He was like jade, he was like a jade-stone,
but later he changed into a cinnabar-steely hue.
How wise he was! How wise!"
Someone asked:
"Does the noble man place great value on rhetoric?"
Reply:
"What the noble man values is substance.
If subject matter outweighs rhetoric, then there is bold bluntness.
But when the rhetoric outweighs subject matter, then there is rhyme prose fù.
When subject matter and rhetoric are balanced, then there is the classic.
When sufficient attention is paid to words and sufficient attention is paid to appearance
then that is the adornment of virtue."
Someone asked,
"As for Gongsun Long's sophistical phrases were in the tens of thousands,
and he took them to be models (fore emulation).
But are they (really) models (for emulation)?"
Reply:
"For cutting down trees to make game boards
or working on leather to make balls
for all these things there are also models.
But anything that fails to conform to model constituted by the former kings
the noble man does not take it to be a model.
Contemplating books is like contemplating mountains and rivers:
Having got up to the Eastern Peak one gets to understand the writhing along of the various other mountains,
and even more that of the little hillocks.
After floating along on the blue sea one gets to understands the murkiness of the Yangtse and the Yellow River,
and even more that of the dried-up marshes.
Crossing a major waterway, having abandoned the ferry, that is an impossibility.
Realising the Way successfully, having abandoned the Five Classics, that is an impossibility.
If someone discard standard excellent fare and has a passion for exotic delicacies–
how can one judge whether he is a connoisseur of dishes?
If someone disregards the Great Sage and prefer the Hundred Masters –
judge whether he is a connoisseur of the Way?"
'A trail through the mountain valleys
one may not get to follow,'
and 'a door facing the wall
one may not get to enter."
Reply: "Through what opening, then, can one become an insider?"
Reply: "Mr Kǒng.
As for Mr Kǒng, he is the door."
Reply: "Did you, sir, get in through that door?"
Reply: "Ah, what a door! Ah, what a door!
The only thing is that in certain ways I did not get in through that door."
Someone wanted to study the Cāngjié and the Shǐpiān (handbooks of Chinese characters).
Comment: "Ah, the scribes! Ah, the scribes.
They do better than to arbitrarily give up on characters!"
Someone asked:
"Suppose there were a man
who he said his name was Confucius,
and who entered through Confucius's door, ascended his main hall,
leaned on Confucius's armrest, and even put on his lower garments,
should he (really) be called "Confucius"?"
Reply: "The polished surface would be the right one,
but the substance would be the wrong one."
"May I ask about this 'substance'?"
Reply: "Something with the substance of a sheep, but with the skin-clothing of a tiger
will be delighted when it sees grass,
and it will be trembling with fear when it sees a jackal
and it will disregard its skin-clothing being that of a tiger."
"The sage stands out like the tiger,
with patterns bold and brilliant!
The noble man stands out like a leopard,
with patterns finer and elegant.
The rhetorician stands out ike the fox,
its patterns dense enough to provide cover."3
A single change of the fox and it turns into a leopard,
and a single change of the leopard and it turns into a tiger!"
If anyone is fond of books and does not focus on the importance of Confucius
he is a (mere) book-peddler;
if someone is fond of philosophical explanations but does not focus on the importance of Confucius
he is a tingle-tangler of philosophical explanations.
As for a noble man, in what he says there is nothing deliberately outrageous,
and in what he listens to there is nothing excessive.
Deliberate outrageousness (in what one says) leads to chaos;
excessiveness (in what one listens to) leads to wickedness.
There have those who have transmitted the Correct Way but little by little turned to humbug;
there never have been any who transmitted humbug and little by little turned to what is correct.
"The Way of Confucius
is straight and easy!"
Someone said:
"As a boy one is brought up on it,
and as an white-haired old man one still is thoroughly confused!
How is it 'straight and easy'?"
Reply:
"The point is (Confucius) does not tackle wickedness (of this world) with wickedness,
nor does he tackle the deceitfulness (of this world) with deceitfulness.
Had Confucius tackled this wickedness with wickedness and if he had tackled this deceitfulness with deceitfulness
then even if someone has ears (to perceive what is correct with) and eyes (to see what is correct with),
how could he manage to straighten himself out (Confucius would never rise above the wickedness and deceitfulness of this world and would indeed not be 'straight and easy'."
"Having heard about many things one should retain then according to what summarises them,
having seen many things one should retain them according to what stands out among them;
if one hears only about few things nothing will summarise them,
and if one sees only few things nothing will stand out among them."
"Of green garments there may be three hundred
but with that colour what can you do with them?
Your silk floss dresses may be three thousand,
but when it is cold what can you do with them?"
The Way of the Noble Man has four ways of being easy:
It has simplicity that is easy to use,
it has relevance that is easy to retain,
it has brilliance that is easy to see,
and it has regularity that is easy to express.
"Only after a raging thunderstorm or driving rain
does one understand the shelter afforded by a great house;
And only after an oppressive rule and an age of oppression
does one fully properly understand why the Sage made those "protective walls".
Of old, Yáng Zhū and Mò Dí stood in the way,
and Mèngzǐ spoke up and opened a path.
That was splendidly done.
In these later times there are those who (again) stand in the way,
I humbly line up with Mencius."
Someone asked:
"Each person takes to be right what he considers right and takes to be wrong what he considers wrong.
Who can straighten this situation out?"
Reply: "When all kind of things get out of order they all depend on heaven;
when all kinds of theories get into a mess they will be sorted out by the various sages."
Someone asks,
"But how is one to judge a Sage and sort things out?"
Reply: "When he is alive there is the person,
when he is no more there are the books.
The principle is the same."
Self-cultivation one makes one's bow,
adjusting one's thinking one makes one's arrows,
establishing moral rectitude one makes one's target,
then, if one lets fly only after one is well-poised,
whenever one lets fly one will hit the target.
As for the inborn nature of man the good and the bad are blended together (in it).
If one cultivates the good one becomes a good person;
if one cultivates the bad one becomes a bad person.
As for the vital energies,
are they not the the horse by which one reaches goodness or badness?"
Someone said,
"Confucius had many professional skills, (荀子，楊注：事，所能也）
but when he found no employment
then, surely, he was stressed and worried like everyone else.
Reply: "The sage (ambiguous in Chinese as in English) rejoices in Heaven and understands destiny.
When when one rejoyces in Heaven (as the source or agent of 天命 "destiny from Heaven") one is unstressed,
and when one understands destiny one is not worried."
Someone asked about incised inscriptions.
Reply: "Ah, Inscriptions! Inscriptions!
Their purpose is making one take care."
"As for the formulations of the Sage
they can be put into practice.
To make others have faith in them
that is what cannot be put into practice.
So the noble man studies hard and energetically puts into practice (what he has learnt).
If one polishes up one's goods before one sells them,
cultivates one's person before on strikes up relations (with others),
ensures the excellence of one's plans before one takes action,
then that is the successful Way.
What the noble man is careful with
is personal statements, ritual propriety, and written records.
If, 'in his relations with his superiors, one does not flatter,
nor, in his relations with those below, one is not arrogant,'1
then one can get somewhere.
Someone objected: "But the noble man will take good care of himself,
where is his relating to others?"
Reply: "Heaven and Earth interact and the myriad kinds of creatures are born,
man and the Way interact and moral achievements are realised.
How should the noble man just 'take good care (of himself)'?"
If you have a passion for something great but you do not act on it,
then that "great" thing is not great.
if you have a passion for what is of high value but you do not act on it
then what is "of high value" thing is not in fact of high value.
Gazing at Heaven's Court above one understands how All under Heaven occupies a humble position!"
The talents of Gōng Yízǐ and of Dǒng Zhòngshū were scintilating.
But if from seeing excellence they did not derive enlightenment,
and if in the use of their mental capacities they had not been unflinching,
who of them would have got anywhere?
Someone asked:
"What about the functions of human-heartedness, moral rectitude, ritual propriety, wisdom, and trustiness?"
Reply:
"Human-heatedness is the dwelling;
moral rectitude is the road;
ritual propriety is the garment;
wisdom is the candlelight;
and trustiness is the warant.
One abides in the house;
travels by the road,
straightens one's garments;
lights the candlelight,
and clasps the warrant.
The noble man may not take any initiative,
but when he does take the initiative, then he gets what he wants."
Ah, to know what one is doing!
Mencius said:
"Now there have been those who knew what they were doing but did not reach perfection;
but there never have been any who did not know what they were doing but reached perfection."
Someone asked about governing one's own person well.
Reply: "Governing oneself well is to accord with Confucius."
The interlocutor continued: "If governing oneself well is to accord with Confucius,
why are the Confucius's so few?"
Reply: "Leading horses (well) is to accord with (the legendary charioteer) Jì,
Isn't that acceptable?"
The interlocutor continued: "When working very large fields, the bristlegrass there will be high,'
when yearning for a person who is far away then 'one's heart will be deeply dissatisfied'."
Reply: "The sun has its rays, and the moon, its light.
If for three years one did not see sun(light), one's eyesight would certainly be lost.
And if for three years one did not see by moonlight, the pupils would certainly grow dim.
After a long period of disuse the spark of life [inside the pupil] dries up,
while the lens collapses inward.
Then a person would be feeling his way around, like a blindman using a staff to locate the path,
or walking in the dark – that's all.
Someone asked, "What does it take to be called human (in the full sense of the word)?"
Reply: "When one opts for taking four things seriously and against neglecting (these) four things as unimportant,
then one may be called human (in the full sense of the word)."
"What are the four things of importance?
Reply: Placing importance on one's speech, actions, appearance, and passions.
When speech is treated as important there will be law,
when action is treated as important there will be virtue,
when appearance is treated as important there will be authority,
when passions are treated as important there will be a proper perspective on things.
"May I ask about the four kinds of neglect as unimportant?"
Reply: "When speech is neglected as unimportant this will attract trouble,
when action is neglected as unimportant this will provoke wrongdoing,
when appearance is neglected as unimportant this will provoke humiliation
when passions are neglected as unimportant then this will provoke indulgence."
"Ritual propriety involves many concrete ritual rules."
Someone said: "If by the evening one has not eaten meat
that meat is bound to dry out;
if by the evening one has not drunk up wine,
that wine is bound to turn sour.
The one hundred toasts between guest and host and the three-fold passing of the wine
is that not an excessive ostentation?
Reply: "If one is down-to-earth without display then one is uncivilised,
if one is ostentatious without being down-to-earth then there is commercialisation,
but if ostentation and down-to-earthness are matched, then there is ritual propriety.
When yon male mountain female (pheasant) is well-fed
it has it achieved its aim in life, hasn't it?"
Someone objected: "Yán Huí with his bamboo basket (of rice) and gourd (of wine), he must have been emaciated!
What do you have to say about that?" (Did he, then, not achieve his aim in life?)
Reply: "When enlightened wisdom is in charge
and all the officials, the oxen and the sheep (note: 當牛做馬,又乖乖如羊) are (like these fat) mountain pheasants,
but when benighted stupidity is in charge
then those with their baskets and gourds, pickers of vegetables, are still also (like these fat) mountain pheasants.
Who cares about their emaciation?
When a thousand jun-weights count as light,
that is because of the strength of Wū Huò.
When baskets and gourds count as a joy,
that is because of Mr Yán's virtue/moral excellence.
Someone asked:
"As for the shorn hide of the plough-ox and the shorn hide of a pure black or red ox, are they different?"
Reply: "They are the same."
"Well then: why not use the plough-ox (hide in ancestral sacrifices)?"
Reply: "To pay filial reverence to spirits,
one would not dare use the plougox.
But when disgorging sheep and stabbing pigs
to entertain guests or to feast (victorious) troops,
it makes no difference whether the beast has been ploughing or has not been ploughing!"
"Men of virtue/moral excellence like to consult sages."
Someone said:
"Of the men of Lǔ few are possessed of moral excellence,
How come they liked to consult Confucius?"
Reply:
"In Lǔ they never quite had what it takes to love to consult Confucius(, in fact).
Had they (really) liked to consult Confucius,
then the state of Lǔ would have become a "Zhōu (dynasty) of the East."
Someone asks:
"Suppose there was a person who leaned against Confucius' wall
strummed the tunes/music of Zhèng and Wèi
or recited the writings of Hán Fēi and Zhuāngzǐ,
would he then be brought into the house through the main door?"
Reply:
"In the regions of the Yí and Mò (barbarians) he would pull such a person in (and welcome him as a disciple);
but when he is leaning against his own gate and wall he would wave him away.
It is such a pity that before the upper garment (of Confucian 經) is completed people turn already to making the lower garments (of the various 邪說 of the non-Confucian 諸子)" 李軌：聖典，本也；諸子末也。
"The sages' ears will not put up with what is wrong,
their mouths will not offend against what is good.
As for the worthies their ears discriminate, and their mouths discriminate.
The ordinary are indiscriminate."
Someone asks about ordinary people.
Reply: "They are all about wealth, honor, and survival." (See 貴生 in LSCQ)
"And the worthies?"
Reply: "They are all about moral rectitude."
"And the sages?"
Reply: "They are all about the spirit."
Observing the worthies one gets and eye for the ordinary people;
observing the sages one gets an eye for worthies;
observing Heaven and Earth one gets an eye for the sages.
There are three kinds of passion in All under Heaven:
The ordinary people have a passion for following their own inclinations;
the worthy have a passion for setting themselves aright;
and the sages have a passion for taking themselves as their masters.
There are three kinds of self-assessment in All under Heaven:
the ordinary people conduct self-eassessment on the basis of their family;
the worthies conduct self-assessment on the basis of their state;
and the sages conduct self-assessment on the basis of All under Heaven.
There are three 'gates' in All under Heaven':
to start from one's own desires,
and to enter through the gate of bestiality;
to start from ritual propriety and moral rectitude,
and to enter through the gate of being human;
and to start from unique wisdom,
and to enter through the gate of sagehood.3
Someone asked:
"What does a gentleman have to do in order to bring serenity to this person of his?"
Reply:
"If in the conduct of his inwardness someone has (French:) envergure and depth
and if in the conduct of his outwardness he is serious and shows self-control
then he can bring serenity to this person of his."
Even in slight matters the noble man is mindful of moral excellence.
Since minor errors do not occur
how could there arise major resentment?
The ears of the superior kind of a gentleman are instructed by virtue/moral excellence
the ears of the inferior kind of gentleman follow his own whims.
If someone has nothing to be ashamed of in his words and nothing to be embarrassed by in his acts,
Confucius would be afraid of him." (...because Confucius feels that no one is morally infallible...)
Someone asks about the Way.
Reply:
"As for 'the Way" it is what leads through,
It leads through to everywhere."
The interlocutor said:
"But can one can get to another place (different from the one intended, by following the Way)?"
Reply:
"Whatever conforms to Yáo, Shùn, and King Wén is the Correct Way.3
The paths having nothing to do with Yao, Shun, and King Wen are divergent paths.
The noble man keeps to the straight path; he does not opt for divergence."
Someone asked about the Way.
Reply:
"The Way is like a road, like a river,
on which carts and boats are rolling and flowing,
"without ceasing, night and day."
Someone said,
"But how does one find the straight Way to follow?"
Reply:
"A road may wind around, but so long as it leads straight to the Xià dynasty, then one follows it
And the river may wind, but so long as it flows to the sea, then one follows it."
The interlocutor said:
"So even if certain actions follow a winding road, so long as they lead straight to the sages,
then one should take them?"
The Way, virtue, human-heartedness, moral rectitude, and ritual propriety –
these must be compared to one person.
By the Way one guides it,
through virtue one makes it virtuous,
through human-heartedness one humanises it,
through rectitude one makes it acceptable,
and through ritual propriety one gives it limbs,
that is Heaven-given.
When these are joined they interpenetrate each other
but when separated, they disperse.
If as one person one controls all the four limbs,
then one's person is 'whole and intact.' "
Someone asked about display of virtue.
Reply: "One must not be deliberate. (???)
One acts out the superior, or one acts out the subordinate." (Remember: 上行下效)
[The questioner went on:] "May I ask about why according to ritual one must not be deliberate?"
Reply:
"If one acts out ritual propiety in one place
and the people profit from that in another place
how is one to be deliberate?"
The interlocutor continued:
"But how is such a person as good as someone who is virtuous WITHOUT ritual propriety?"
Reply:
"Ritual propriety is the very substance.
A person who lacks ritual decorum,
how could he regarded as charismatic?"
Someone asked about Heaven.
Reply:
"How I relate to Heaven?
I see its performance through non-assertive action."
Someone asked:
"(Wait a minute:) That which carved out the various shapes,
was that not Heaven."
Reply: "I think he did not in fact carve or cut these out.
If Heaven had carved or cut out the creatures,
where would they (the creatures) have got their vital energy to be sufficiently supplied?" (They would be dead sculptures.)
"Regarding Lǎozǐ's propositions about the Way and its Power,
it is just that I find things to adopt there.
But when it comes to 'to chiselling away human-heartedness and rectitude,'
and 'curring off ritual proprietyh and study'
I will have nothing of it."
"How could I open up and enlighten (others)?
Only the sages may be taken to be able to open up and enlighten others,
As for others they make things wilt/fade.
Truly great are the sages;
Theirs are the perfect pronouncements.
Open them up, and one gains a vast vision of the whole world,
Block them off, and one does not even see the inside of one's walls.
"The sages' pronouncements
are like water and fire."
Someone asked about this "water and fire?"
"This water: the more one plumbs it, the deeper it gets;
the further one would pursue it, the farther one goes.
This fire: the more you use it, the brighter it burns;
the longer you make it last, the stronger it gets.
If indeed anyone governed All under Heaven well
without relying on ritual propriety and decorum and the Five Teachings/Principles (父義、母慈、兄友、弟恭、子孝五種倫理)
then I would consider the Yellow Emperor, Yáo and Shùn to be (historical excrescences) and superfluities. (But there never was such a case!)
Someone said:
"In the very distant past there were no legal rules, and yet good political order prevailed.
So laws are not the means by which to create good political order.
Reply:
"As for the world of great disorder.
these the sages abhorred.
Therefore legal rules began with Fǔxí and were completed with Yáo.
Without Fǔxí and without Yáo,
ritual propriety and moral rectitude would be just babble,
and the sages would not have opted for them."
Someone asked:
As for ritual propriety in the far-flung regions
which ritual propriety, which music is the right one?"
Reply:
"One judges them by the standards of the Central States."
Someone asks:
"Then which are the Central States?"
Reply:
"Where the five administrative practices are applied,
and the seven crops cultivated;3
and the land is located at the center of heaven and earth –
this counts as the Central States.
When one goes beyond these boundaries is anyone there in the true sense a human?"
The sages' rule of the known world "under heaven" is as follows:
they set up constraints in it them using rites and music.
If there are none such, one is (like) a wild bird,
if there are divergent ones one is a mò-barbarian.
I see various thinkers belittle ritual propriety and music,
but I have never seen the sages belittle ritual propriety and music.
Who can write, but not with a brush,
or speak without a tongue?
I see Constant Way of Heaven as the tongues and brushes of sovereigns and kings [of antiquity]."
As for 'wisdom', it is (a way of) understanding.
But as for wisdom,
no matter whether used or not used,
whether added to or not added to
will not swell up or diminish as a result (is not incremental, like knowledge and understanding).
A deep understanding of the construction of implements and contraptions, boats and carts, houses and chambers
definitely is a source from which ritual propriety flows. (One follows a regular "ritual" pattern of procedures in all these matters...)
Someone asked about the Grand Sound.
Reply:
"It is not that of thunder, nor that of a thunderclap.
It goes on rumbling, booming
and in the long run it becomes more and more fully resounding:
it stands in for all the sages." (The Grand Sound is of a higher order than physical grand noises.)
Someone asked:
"Is the Way based on something, or is it not based on anything (and autonomous)?".
Reply:
"If something is acceptable, one bases oneself on it,
when it is not one changes it for something better."
Someone asked about non-assertive action?
Reply: "What is that good for?
In olden days, Shùn and Yǔ inherited their rank from Yáo
and they practiced the Way of Yáo.
Their laws and ordinances were were public;
their rites and music were clear.
Arms hanging, hands folded they watchedWell the people in All under Heaven flourishing.
THAT was "non-assertive action"!
When in the aftermath of (the tyrants) Jié and Zhòu
laws and ordinances being abandoned
rites and music having gone into decline.
then to sit at at one's ease and watch the people in All Under Heaven dying–
Someone asks:
"In highest antiquity, they smothered their people's ears and eyes,
because if they saw or heard,
if they had seen anything it was hard to hide it,
and if they had heard something it was hard to block it up."
Reply:
"When Heaven first bestowed life on the people,
it made their eyes see and their ears hear.
Thus they see things and these are ritually correct,
and they listen to things and these are musically correct.
If they watch what is not ritually proper
and listen to what is not musically proper
then even if one is governing these people
how can one get to smother (their eyes and ears)?"
Someone asked about newness and shoddiness.
Reply:
"If it is new, wear it;
and if it is shoddy, either add to it or shorten it."
Someone asked,
"In the most distant past it is for charisma that one cared,
and it was not for ritual propriety that one cared.
When small children love whom they love,
and when colts and calves follow whom they follow
how is that for reasons of ritual propriety?"
Reply:
"Ah, yes! The infant and the calf!
The infant and the calf will care for their mother, but will not care for their father.
When it is the mother one cares for, that is love,
when it is the father one cares for that is respect.
To relate to the mother but not to the father
that is not quite as good as goodness towards both of them."
An adherent of the school of fraudsters said:
"As for the plans of a fraudster
they can subdue the enemy's forces without a battle,
these are (as supernaturally efficient as the) Yáos and Shùns of this world!"
Reply:
"To ubdue the enemy's forces without a battle:
that is to be a Yáo or a Shùn.
But to drench necks and soak people's lapels (in blood?),
is that to be a Yáo and Shùn?
Flaunting "jade" but in fact flogging (mere) stones (instead)
THAT is to be a fraudster!"
The interlocutor asked
"Given the choice to either become a scheming fraud or to go without such,
which is preferable?"
Reply:
"It is better to go without."
The interlocutor continued:
"If you led the Six Armies,
whom would you employ, then?"
Reply:
"When the driver knows his way
then all the scheming frauds of this world will be in his service.
When the driver does not know where he is going
then all the scheming frauds of this world will be his rivalling enemies.
Therefore he who is governing this world
must simply pay close attention to the driver, that is all."
The interlocutor continued:
Does the ruler have to rely on punitive campaigns to overawe the vassal lords.
Given the power of stratagems and deceit
how can he possibly do without?"
Reply:
"When for overawing the princes with one's authority, one needs to rely on scheming deceit,
that is acceptable enough.
But this is not as good as overawing the lords
without having to have recourse to scheming deceit."
Someone asked,
"But if there are no strategic deceit,
then how is one to proceed to carry out the punitive campaigns?"
Reply:
"Even if one absolutely has no alternative but to launch a punitive attack,
then isn't there (the military manual entitled) Model for the marshal?
What need is there for strategems and deception?"
"The arts of Shēn Bùhài and Hán Fēi
are ultimate of inhumanity.
How can one treat humans like oxen or goats?
If one treats humans like oxen or goats,
then will foxes and jackals, ants and worms not be performing the Lóu and Là festivals?"
Someone objected:
"But when the knife is blunt
and the brush is not trimmed,
should it not be appropriate to apply the grindstone (and whatever is used to trip and 'sharpen' a brush)?"
Reply:
"As for being a grindstone for humans, Qín was supreme at that!"
Someone asked,
"Is 'physical performance following job description' at variance with the Way?
Why, then, is it so natural?"
Reply:
"Why does it have to be 'forms and names'?
Games like Go, swordplay, acrobatic stunts(?) and illusionistic tricks –
all these are also natural (but not for that reason morally commendable).
He who follows what is great (in what is natural) creates the correct way,
and he who follows the petty (in what is natural) creates a heretical way."
Someone asked:
"Are Shēn Bùhài's and Hán Fēi's laws against the 'law'?"
Reply:
"As for 'law'
this (properly) refers to the laws of Yú, Shùn, Chéng-Táng (of Shāng), and of the (early) Zhōu.
Are these like Shēn Bùhài and Hán Fēi's? Are these like Shēn Bùhài and Hán Fēi's?"
As for Zhuāng Zhōu, Shēn Bùhài and Hán Fēi,
if they had not opposed and belittled the Sage (i.e. Confucius)
but had instead delved into all the chapters (of the works relating to him),
then the sons of the Yáns (Confucius's disciple Yán Huí) and the later offspring of the Míns (Confucius's disciple Mín Zǐqiàn)
what could they have done/where would they have been? (They would have paled into insignificance by conparison with these writers.)
Someone asked:
(But) does not Zhuāng Zhōu have his points?
Reply:
"The reduction of desires."
"And does Zōu Yǎn have his points?"
Reply:
"Self-management.
But when it comes to (Zhuāng) Zhōu, with him there was no duty between ruler and subject,
and as for (Zōu) Yǎn with him there is no understanding between Heaven and Earth (only metaphysical correspondences???):
even if we were neighbours, I would never visit them."
Someone asks about spirit.
Reply: "It is the heart/mind."
"May I ask what you mean?"
Reply: "The heart and mind, when it merges into Heaven it acts out Heaven;
when it merges into Earth it acts out Earth.
Heaven and Earth being supernatural and magical, are unfathomable,
but when the heart and mind merges (into Heaven and Earth), it will still fathom them out.
How much more (when it merges into) other people!
How much more (when it merges into) the guiding principles of things!"
"May I ask about merging one's mind into the Sages?"
Reply: "Long ago, Confucius merged his heart and mind into King Wen,
and he attained to his level.
Yan Yuan likewise merged his heart and mind into Confucius,
did not quite attain to his level, by the skin of his teeth.
One's spirit depends on what one merges oneself into, that is all.
Heaven is supernatural and Heaven is magical,
it shines upon and supervises the Four Regions.
Heaven is subtle and Heaven is pure,
for the myriad kinds of creatures/things it creates their natural kinds.
The heart and mind of man – how supernatural it is!
'If one exercises it in practice it lives;
if one lets go of it it dies.' (Mencius 6A8)
The sages preserve their supernatural spirit and seek perfection.
They complete the great concord in all-under-heaven;
they confer great benefit upon all-under-heaven;
and they bring harmony and unity to the contact between the heavenly and the human realms
"The dragon coiled up in the mud (waiting for the right moment for action),
It is the water lizard that indulges itself.
Ah, those lizards, lizards!
How can they get any glimpse of the aspirations of a dragon?"
Someone asked: "But does a dragon necessarily want to fly up up into the sky?"
Reply: "When the times comes to fly, then it flies;
when the times comes to hide itself, then it hides.
Whether it flies or hides,
its feeding must never be arbitrary;
but can the form not be externally controlled."
The interlocutor continued: "If a sage will not be externally controlled
then what were they doing at Yǒulǐ (where the undoubted sage Duke Wén of Zhōu was famously imprisoned)?"
Reply: "The dragon is a dragon by virtue of its being not externally controlled.
The sage is a sage by virtue of his being not being manacled."
When writings are not in accordance with the classics,
they are the wrong writings;
when speech is not in accordance with the classics
it is wrong speech.
When words and writings are not in accordance with the classics
they may proliferate, but they are excrescences.
Someone said:
"I transmit, but do not create." (as Confucius said LY 7.1)
So why have you created the Tai xuan jing?"
Yangzi said:
"Its content I have transmitted.
Only the book itself have I created."
Someone said:
"What was the mystery for?"
Reply:
"It was for human-heartedness and rectitude."
The interlocutor continued:
"But who is not for human-heartedness?
Who is not for rectitude?
Reply:
"Do not mix in other things, that is all."
Someone asked whether the classics were hard or easy to read.
Reply:
"That is a matter of the continued existence or lack (of the right people)."
The interlocutor did not understand.
(Yáng Xióng) explained:
"If the right persons exists then it is easy;
if no such person exists it is hard.
Jìzǐ of Yánlíng, when it comes to music
was quite good.
But if the interest in music was slackening
then even someone like Jìzǐ could do nothing about it.
When under conditions of rituals the music of the Zhōu all things are provided for (by the right sort of people),
then everything will count as not hard;
but when under conditions of ritual and and music of the Qín all things are not provided for (by the right sort of people)
how can this be other than difficult?
Wearing proper upper garments but not wearing proper lower garments,
I'm not sure that is OK;
wearing proper lower garments but not wearing proper upper garments,
I'm not sure that is OK.
Upper and lower garments must in agreement.
Someone asked about the decorous (wén).
Reply:
"Proper order."
He went on to ask about the military.
Reply:
"Overcoming."
He did not quite understand.
Yáng Xióng continued:
"When matters get into their proper sequence this is called "proper order".
When one overcomes the egotism of one's self that is called "overcoming".
Working towards something and carrying it through
taking the initiative for something and becoming a shining star,
that is moral charisma.
Someone said:
"But those who understand moral charisma are few, (LY15.4)
how can one become a shining star?
Reply:
"If when they recognise one, one does the right thing,
and when they do not recognise one, one also does the right thing:
then one's shining stardom is great indeed!
If people must recognise one before one does one's thing
then one's "shining stardom" is surely a petty thing."
Someone said:
"The gentleman is upset about dying without leaving a name for himself,
but surely one uses power to establish a name.
A "name" is what high officials can hope for."
Reply:
"The noble man will hope for a "name" based on charismatic virtue.
The rulers of Wèi魏, Qí, Zhào and Chǔ
weren't short of being rich and noble,
but where did they achieve a "name" for themselves?
On the other hand Zhèng Zǐzhēn of Gǔkǒu
was unbending in his aspirations as the ploughed the fields below the cliffs
and his name reverberated throughout the capital.
How should this be because he was a high official? How?"
Someone asked about humans.
Reply:
"They are hard to understand."
The interlocutor continued:
"Why are they difficult to understand?"
Reply:
"The difference between Mount Tài and an anthill,
or between the Yangzi and the Yellow River on the one hand and drainage ditches on the other
is by no means hard to make.
But the difference between a great sage and a great rhetorical sham
that is hard to make.
Ah!
Someone who is capable of keeping apart similar things will count as having no difficulty with this.
Someone asked:
"Are there things you opt for in Zòu Yǎn and Zhuāng Zhōu?"
Reply:
"If something is in accordance with virtue then I opt for it,
if it is mistaken, then I do not opt for it."
"What do you call in accordance with virtue and what mistaken."
Reply:
"When pronouncing on Heaven, Earth, and Man (三才)
then when something is principled according to the classics, it is in accordance with virtue,
when it is not, then it is mistaken.
Mistaken talk the noble man will not cause to come from his mouth."
Someone asked about being clear about things.
Reply:
"It is a matter of the subtlties."
The interlocutor continued:
"The subtleties, how do they lead to clarity?"
Reply:
"When one recognises the subtleties
one surely is clear about what is confused."
Clear hearing, clear sight, are these not the most important things?
If one has no clear hearing this amounts to having no ears;
if one has no clear sight this amounts to having no eyhes.
But may I ask about the higher order of clear hearing and clear sight?
Reply:
That is mysterious indeed.
Only Heaven counts as having (that kind of) clear hearing,
only Heaven counts as having (that kind of) clear sight.
As for being able raise one's sight high (to the virtues) and to direct one's ears low (to the common people)
is that not for Heaven to do/a Heavenly thing to do?
Someone asked:
"A person who understands all small matters,
can he be called a (true) Master?"
Reply:
"What Master would that be?
What Master would that be?
The petty matters in this world are not few:
if one understands all of these
would one be called a (true) Master?
The important thing in a Master
is that he has great understanding.
A master of petty understanding
is surely vulgar."
Someone asked:
"Among the birds there is the phoenix,
among the animals there is the unicorn,
but can all birds and beasts become phoenixes and unicorns (respectively)?
Answer:
"The relation between the (ordinary) birds and the phenix,
and the relation betwen the (ordinary) beasts and the unicorn
are a matter of both (external) form and (inner) nature:
how does that apply to the relation between the (ordinary) humans and the sage?"
Someone asked:
"It is extreme
how the Way of the Sages fails to do any good to mediocrity.
Since it is the Sages that people read but mediocrity that they practise,
presumably one should/might as well get rid of the sages."
Reply:
"It is extreme
how you, Sir, fail to understand things.
When it is the Sages they read but mediocrity that they practise
they still have heard about things.
Getting rid of the Sages is pointless.
The one who caused the Qín to engage in this pointlessness,
was that not Lǐ Sī?
He threw the (books of the Sages) into the fire."
Someone asked:
"What should man value most?"
Reply:
"Man should value wisdom highest."
Reply:
"Many have lost their lives because of their wisdom.
Why value it highest?"
Reply:
"In ancient times Gāo Yāo composed the Dìmò chapter with his wisdom.
He was far from getting killed (for that);
Jízǐ composed the Hóngfàn for King Wǔ with his wisdom,
and he was far from getting killed (for that)."
Thunder shakes in the sky,
Wind presses in on the mountains,
Clouds blowing to the four corners of the Earth,
Rain flows into the abyss—
That is their business!
Lord Wǔ of Wèi and Wǔ Qǐ were sailing on the West River,
and they appreciated the security provided by river and mountains.
Wu Qi said: "The fate of the kingdom lies in the de of the ruler, not in the geographic security."
Yangzi said: "Beautifully said!
If Wǔ Qǐ's making the military situation secure had been like this at all times,
then how could even Tài Gōng have surpassed him?
When the time is not right then to look forward to it,
when the road is not the right one then to walk on it,
then surely one cannot reach one's aim.
The Qín officials turned against the legal arrangements of the Qín,
and the legal arrangements of the Qín had turned against the legal arrangements of the Sages;
The Qín defied the Way of Heaven and Earth on a huge scale,
and the defiance of Qín by Heaven and Earth was also on a huge scale.
The Sages had what it takes to emulate Heaven and Earth
and in their person they formed a triad with them.
Someone asked: Does the sage, on occasion, bow to circumstances?
"Yes he does."
"When does he bow to circumstances?"
"As for the relation between Confucius and Nánzǐ,
he did not wish to visit her;
and as for Yáng Hǔ,
he did not want to pay respect to him.
He visited the one he wasn't going to visit
and paid respect to one whom he wasn't goint to respect.
How could one say he did not bow to circumstances?"
The interlocutor asked: "Is the noble man chary with his (free) time.
Reply: The noble man, when in ofice, wishes to perform the duties of that office,
and when at home he wishes to show up his chosen Way.
In performing his tasks he is indefatigable,
in teaching others he is untiring.
How would he get to have time?
Someone said: "(We are told:) if there is a successor to the Zhōu,
then even after a hundred generations
it can be ascertained to be the successor.
But the Qín have already succeeded the Zhōu
and without relying on the rituals of the Xià they created political order.
Does that not prove a point? (i.e. the point that a successor dynasty to the Qín was not going to be perennial)
The words of the sage (Confucius) are from Heaven,
and can Heaven be talking nonsense?
Those who continued the heritage of the Zhōu did not yet desire universal peace
If they had desired universal peace
rejecting the rituals of the Xià and using another ideology
they surely had no way of achieving their aim.
Dazzling bright is the sunlight,
and all the eyes make use of it;
all-encompassing is the Way of the Sages,
and all the minds make use of it.
Heaven and Earth are plain and easy, and the Sages model themselves on these.
Why are the Five Classics so disjointed and incongruous?
"The disjointedness and incongruousness,
these are presumably the means by which a plainness and easiness is produced.
If the classics had been too plain and too easy,
then what use would there have been for the disjointedness and the incongruousness?
Someone said: "The Sage is of no use to ordinary men."
Reply: "What is of use to the people of this world
is the granaries.
Taking from it is like exhausing it's supplies.
Confucius had spiritual magic
Petty personalities use him to achieve petty things
big personalities use him to achieve great things.
So even mountains and streams, hills and mounds, shrubs and trees, birds and beasts
are thriving (through him).
If one does not use the sage
then the spiritual magic will also disappear.
Then what to do?"
Someone asked: "Does the Sage divine about Heaven?|
Reply: "He divines about Heaven and Earth.
"Well, in that case, how does the court astrologer differ from him?"
Reply: "The astrologer uses the heavens to divine about men.
The Sage uses men to divine about Heaven."
Someone asked: "For the stars there are Gān Dé and Shí Shēn,
What were their views?"
Reply: "Things depend on virtue, they do not depend on the stars.
When it is virtue that predominates then it takes the stars as the indicator
when it is the stars that predominate then they take the virtue as the indicator.
Someone asked about (the concept of) a "great man".
"Not to make the petty one's business is to be a "great man".
"What about pettiness?"
"Making what is neither ritual nor rectitude one's business, that counts as particularly petty."
The pronouncements of a sage are wide-ranging like Heaven,
the pronouncements of a worthy are closely relevant like Earth.
As for what produces the jade sound
its substance must be jade.
The Sages open there mouths and come up with pronouncements,
they give free rein to their brush and come up with books.
Those pronouncement one may hear but cannot be made to tire of,
those books one may look over but they cannot be understand completely.
Listening carefully to earlier generations
and open-mindedly examining what comes afterwards:
no mirror comes closer (to reality) than such practice.
Someone asked: "How does one have to move in order to be regarded as awesom?
"Regard others as awesome!"
"How must one move so as to get humiliated by others?"
"Humiliate others!"
As for being regarded as awesome and being humiliated,
in all cases these have their origin in oneself.
Someone asked: "Ritual propriety is hard to impose on this world."
"Hard it is. That is why one has to IMPOSE it on this world." (Otherwise one could just let things take their natural course.)
As when a barbarian waits and squats indecorously on the ground,
or when a little child sucks and and then gulps it down,
what is there to IMPOSE in such a case?
In some cases it is by nature, in other cases by imposition,
but when behavior attains to the name (ritual propriety) they are one and the same.
"One can tell that the bow stretched taught
